conclusion: The problem involves determining the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface of a hemispherical shell where light rays are transmitted.
The hemispherical shell has inner radius R, outer radius sqrt(2)R, and refractive index n. A parallel beam of light with cross-sectional radius R is incident on the inner surface.
At the inner surface, light rays refract into the transparent medium. The angle of incidence i depends on the ray's position relative to the axis.
For a ray striking the inner surface at distance r from the axis, the angle of incidence i is alpha = arcsin(r/R).
Using Snell's law at the inner surface, sin(theta) = r/(nR).
After refraction at the inner surface, rays travel through the medium toward the outer surface.
Refracted rays converge toward the center O of the hemispherical shell.
At the outer surface, refracted rays exit the shell into air. Using Snell's law, sin(r_exit) = n sin(theta).
To find the radius of the circular boundary, consider the ray striking the inner surface at maximum distance r = R.
For the ray at r = R, the angle of incidence is 90 degrees, and the angle of refraction inside the shell is theta = arcsin(1/n).
The radial distance of the ray at the outer surface is proportional to sin(theta), giving r_boundary = sqrt(2)R sin(arcsin(1/n)).
